story: Furloughing has worked but unemployment is creeping up.Keeping folk in work and creating new jobs through investment in necessary public works is essential.Whether broadband, new council housing or retrofitting older homes and schools, therersquos things that need done and willing hands to do them.Itrsquos another reason why itrsquos good to see cafes, pubs and restaurants reopening.People work in them, as well as customers welcoming the socialisation just as much as the food and drink on offer.It wonrsquot be easy for owners, as social distancing requirements make it awkward and necessary hygiene rules also impact.Itrsquos also the case that some just wonrsquot be able to reopen as theyrsquore just not able to meet the rules or make a living under them.Itrsquos why the Chancellor should extend the furlough, as in France and other countries, to support those businesses until they can.In the interim, as with this paperrsquos laudable campaign to shop local, we should all try and support local venues.Parliament this week again considered trade and proposed new deals with the USA and other countries.But as with unemployment, whatrsquos creeping out is frightening.I took part in a discussion hosted by Trade Justice International which had representatives from the NFU, RSPCA and other far from radical groups, all of whom expressed concern.Indeed, an NFU petition has gathered over one million signatures.Chlorinated chicken has dominated the headlines but whatrsquos becoming clear is thatrsquos not the least of the threats, repugnant enough as it is.The whole treatment of animals is done with little care for their welfare, let alone those that work in the sector or for consumers who buy the product.Cheap food imports are heralded by the Tory Government, but they come at a price thatrsquoll be paid by hard-working local farmers and all of us in what wersquore forced to eat.

title: column-much-enjoy-preston-seton-gosford
story: For many, foreign holidays have already passed or been cancelled, would be too expensive to book at this late stage, or they do not want to take either the health or financial risk of booking one. So the lure of the staycation has become attractive to many for the first time and, luckily being in East Lothian, we have plenty to keep us entertained.We have a huge number of attractions, whether that be our numerous world-renowned golf courses, the nationally recognised National Museum of Flight and Scottish Seabird Centre in North Berwick, or as one of Scotlandrsquos premier coastal destinations for food and drink.What always interests me is that there is so much available that not everyone knows everything. I am often struck by people not knowing some of the sites in my ward of Preston, Seton and Gosford. Therefore, I thought this week I would take the opportunity to plug them and encourage you to visit us.To start in the west of the ward in Prestonpans exists the Prestonpans Murals Trail, which is made of over  pieces of art, and depicts the townrsquos culture and history.This includes murals on its witch hunts, industrial past, the influence on famous conservationist John Muirrsquos early le, and relation with migration both to and from Scotland ndash well worth a few hoursrsquo walk around the town.Also in the town there is the unappreciated Preston Tower, a structure with parts still standing from the th century. It is a one-of-a-kind building, with dferent parts and floors having been added over the years and other bits destroyed since it was first built.Currently it isnrsquot open but Prestonpans Community Council has been pushing to get it in a fit state so that the people of Prestonpans can truly benefit from this one-of-a-kind building.Moving east into Cockenzie and Port Seton, next to the harbour is the  Waggonway Museum. It is a fantastic museum and project that tells the story of the arearsquos extensive industrial history, including of the Tranent-Cockenzie Waggonway, built in  and associated with the coal and salt industries.Nearby sits Cockenzie House, a mansion and gardens dating from the th century. It is now home to a brilliant wee cafe and numerous craft businesses well worth a visit.In between Longniddry and Port Seton sits Seton Colligate Church, considered ldquoone of the finest medieval collegiate churches in Scotland. It was built in the late s by landowner Lord Seton so the community of priests could pray for his familyrsquos salvation.Finally on the coast there is Longniddry Bents, East Lothian largest tourist attraction. It is a beautul stretch of coastline home to a large iety of wildle, including many types of birds, voles and seals.Soyou are having a staycation this summer, visit the Preston, Seton and Gosford area and, whilst here, support our local cafes, shops, restaurants and pubs.

title: letter-it-act-vandalism
story: Today we are faced with a proposal to turn part of one of these beautul natural sites, in a designated conservation area, into an unsightly car park.Having been born and brought up in North Berwick and able to take advantage of the foresight of our forefathers, I was astonished to find not only that the proposal had been lsquoapprovedrsquo, but that it had been made at all. This is a vulnerable site and the suggestion of lsquotemporaryrsquo use is no guarantee.I am well aware of the problems of parking in our commercially vibrant High Street and all the efforts made over the years to come up with a solution.But parking cars on Elcho Green, a uniquely placed recreational facility for young and old, is not one of them. It would be an act of vandalism comparable with covering the gravestones in the old graveyard, which from a parking point of view would be even more convenient.George Finlayson CMG CVOCraigleith ViewNorth Berwick

title: tims-tales-little-red-riding-hood-wee-rud
story: THERE wis yince a young lassie carsquod Wee Rud. She wis carsquod Wee Rud cause whenever she gaed oot, she wore a rud hoodie. So her pals gied her that nickname, ater the story aboot Wee Rud Riding Hood.Wee Rud hud missed her grandma awfy much durin the lockdoon. She hud spoken tae her oan the computer, but that wasnae the same. Shersquod missed her hugs and the smell orsquo soup in her hoose.Sae when the lockdoon wis being lted, Wee Rud asked her mither: ldquoCan I gang tae grandmarsquos noo Her mither smiled. She understood how hard it hud bin: ldquoAye darlin, yer allowed noo, she will huv missed ye tae.Wee Rud jumped up n doon in wi joy. She packed a basket fu orsquo cakes she hud learnt tae bake during the lockdoon, and gied her ma a wee cheerio kiss.ldquoDinnae forget, gang straight tae grandmarsquos hoose, her mither said. ldquoDinnae footer aboot alang the way and mind no tae talk tae ony wolves.ldquoAye, dinnae worry ma, said Wee Rud, ldquoIrsquoll be carefu I ken the rules.Wee Rud wis a clever lass. She kent a wolf hud been hangin aboot, following folk an eatin grandmas. It wis a gye sleekit creature, it kent how tae hide and trick ye. But Wee Rud wis mair clever, she kent how tae keep safe frae it.She saw the wolf but she wisnae scared. She kept her distance and gied him a wee smirk as she went oan her way tae her grandmarsquos hoose.Wee Rud knocked oan her grandmarsquos door and gaed in. ldquoGranny itrsquos me! Wee Rud! Irsquove brought ye some cakes. I baked them masel.Her grandma stairted tae greet. They were tears orsquo joy, not sorrow, fir she hud missed her beloved Wee Rud sae much. They hugged sae tight their een near popped oot!ldquoYe gang ben the hoose wi thae cakes an Irsquoll put oan a cup orsquo tea, and wersquoll have a richt guid blether, said grandma.While Wee Rud wis putting the cakes oan the coffee table, her grandma came wi the tea. Wee Rud telt her grandma that she hud seen the wolf skulking aboot, but that shersquod flung him a deefie.ldquoGuid lass, said Grandma, ldquothat wolf is a richt sleekit creature, but noo that we ken his tricks we can change the story. They baith laughed.But the wolf wisnae laughing, he wis angry. It couldnae get intae the hoose tae eat grandma. Wee Rud hud bin tae clever.Ater huvin a braw time wi her gran, Wee Rud gied her another hug and left fir hame.Wee Rud arrived back at her hoose wi a happy shine oan her face. ldquoIt wis sae nice tae see Grandma, she said tae her mither.But the wolf wasnae happy in fact he wis ragin. ldquoThis isnae how the story is supposed tae be, he said tae himself, ldquoshersquos supposed tae break the rules and I get intae her grandmarsquos hoose and eat her.Just then, twa nurses were passin by oan their way tae work and heard whit the wolf said.ldquoAye weel, that lassie wis wise tae ye, and so are we, they said.They picked up a stick and waved it in the air, and the wolf ran away.Noo it wis the wolf that wis feart.It looked for ither folk tae follow but noo people kent its tricks and sae it didnae hae much orsquo a chance tae eat grannies onymair.The story hud been changed by Wee Rud, and she hud a wee laugh every time she thocht aboot it.And her grandma wis richt pleased she hudnae been scoffed by the wolf, thanks tae the wisdom orsquo her granddaughter.

title: road-closed-work-continues-dunbar-east-beach
story: Work resumed on improving the beach earlier this month after it was halted by the coronavirus pandemic.The works, which also aim to protect neighbouring Lamer Street, come after several years of discussion.Now, as part of the works, a section of the street from Woodbush to Stable Court will close from tomorrowuntil the end of September.Access to the two streets will be maintained, along with emergency access.Sand on the beach had disappeared due to coastal erosion, with a solution to attempt to restore the beach to how it once looked finally agreed upon earlier this year.Previously, consideration was given to importing sand from where but that was ruled out due to cost and the risk of it being washed away.Now, work is being carried out to see the construction of a breakwater at the southern end of the beach, with the existing groyne refurbished.Rock armour is also being created and will be put in place at the toe of the seawall.

title: coronavirus-poll-scots-support-another-lockdown-second-wave-occurs
story: In the study carried out by YouGov, % of people ldquostrongly support the idea of full measures being introduced in the event of a second wave, with a further % ldquosomewhat supportive of the idea.Meanwhile just under one in tenof Scots would ldquostrongly oppose the second lockdown, with another % ldquosomewhat opposing the idea.The remaining % of the responded as ldquodonrsquot know.The YouGov poll surveyed  adults.It comes as figures in Scotland revealed there had been no deaths of people who tested positive for the virus recorded in the past week ndash meaning the toll remains at  ndash and only one in the past  days.The First Minister described this as the ldquoincredible progress made since the country went into lockdown.In the last few weeks Scots have been able to enjoy more freedoms, including the reopening of pubs, restaurants and the tourism sector.Another YouGov poll of the same number of adults revealed that % of people in Scotland would not have a coronavirus vaccine when it became available.The vast majority ndash around %, said they would take the vaccine, with a further % responding as ldquodonrsquot know.

title: former-coastguard-station-turned-beachfront-home
story: East Lothian Councilrsquos planning officials had previously rejected the application to convert the former station, which looks onto East Beach, Dunbar, into a small house after ruling it did not provide enough lsquooutlookrsquo and lsquoamenityrsquo for future occupants.However, a meeting via Skype of the councilrsquos Local Review Body overturned the refusal on appeal after councillors ruled the proposal was better than leaving the building to fall into disrepair.And they questioned whether the design of the new property, which featured extensive glass frontage to let in light, would, in fact, make the amenity more acceptable.Planning officers had estimated the new one-bedroom property would offer just nine square metres of living space in the proposed kitchen living area.The review body was told that there was no set standard for amenity and outlook when it came to conversions like the one put forward for the building, on the townrsquos Lamer Street.Instead, Leigh Taylor, council planning advisor, said it was down to the inidual officer involved.He said: ldquoThere is no exact standard, it is a judgement that has to be made by each case officer.ldquoIn this case, despite the entire east facebeing entirely glazed, it was judged there would not be sufficient outlook and amenity for the occupant.Sutherland and Co Architects Ltd, the agents, had argued that concern about a lack of amenity and outlook for occupants should be dismissed because the property wouldlook out onto the beach, a point they said was made to planners at the time of the original application.In a statement to the review body, they said: ldquoWe made the point that the proposal includes a balcony and ground to the rear for amenity. The site is also opposite the beach.Councillor Sue Kempson, review body member and ward councillor, said she believedit was important to see the building used for a new purpose and did not feel the lack of amenity was a problem, adding: ldquoNot everyone wants a garden.Fellow member Councillor Neil Gilbert agreed, adding: ldquoA building like this, the longer it is left the more it deteriorates. It has to find a new purpose.Councillor Norman Hampshire, review body chairman and ward member, also upheld the appeal.He said: ldquoIt has to have another use either as commercial or residential and I think residential is a good fit for this building. It will give it a long-term future because someone will look after it and keep it to a high standard.The review body agreed unanimously to support the appeal and allow planning permission with conditions for the conversion.

title: hot-tub-suites-looking-sea-among-new-plans-hotel
story: The ambitious proposals would see a three-storey building built between the Bayswell Park Hotel and the clfs to the north.Nine new suites could be created as part of the plans, which would also see a new restaurant built.According to a supporting statement included within the planning application: ldquoThe existing business model is barely sustainable, and the overarching objective of the development is to invest c.pound, in infrastructure improvements to secure the future of the hotel.ldquoThe development proposals will address weaknesses, strengthen the enterprise, promote higher occupancy levels, deliver a much-improved standard of service that will attract customers and, most importantly, facilitate the delivery of a top-quality hotel.The proposals would see changes made to the existing hotel building, as well as the construction of a new annexe.Inside the hotel, which dates back more than  years, four single rooms would be altered to create two double twin rooms.On the western side of the hotel, which is on the townrsquos Bayswell Park, a new dining area would be created.The new -cover restaurant and improved lounge bar would see the removal of the conservatory and the construction of ldquogreatly improved facilities.According to the supporting statement: ldquoThe present areas are too small, and the new restaurant and lounge bar will provide a spacious attractive welcoming ambiance. The comfortable, high-quality dining and relaxation space will be available for both resident guests and for non-resident clients.The new annexe would offer visitors impressive views over the clfs and out to the North Sea.Drawings show the three-storey building ndash with three suites on each floor ndash built into the sloping land, with outdoor hot tubs.The statement reads: ldquoThe existing hot tub suites are spectacularly unique incredibly popular and are delivering high premium occupancy rates and attracting guests to Dunbar from all over Scotland and from the north of England.ldquoThe present number and type of letting rooms is not sufficient to sustain a business model which includes a very high level of service provision ndash particularly when some potential revenue income sources are not deliverableor have greatly declinedndash over recent years.ldquoConsolidation of four single rooms into two double twin rooms will result in the number of bedrooms within the hotel being reduced by two, with the combined proposals showing a net increase of seven rooms.Other works proposed for the hotel include the installation of a lt and ambulant toilet facilities, as well as improving the parking outside the hotel.The proposed developments, which are being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department, are the latest changes at the hotel, which currently has  bedrooms and five suites.In , a dining room and conservatory extension was built, and in  a decked area and four private hot tubs were added.Community councillors in the town had mixed views on the proposals, which were discussed on Monday evening.Jacquie Bell, secretary of the group, said there were neighbours who were ldquoreally, really concerned about the proposals.She noted that social media had also given a mixed picture, with some questioning the design of the annexe building and the safety of building on that area of land.However, community councillor Craig Rapson said: ldquoThere is a need for hotel accommodation in Dunbar.ldquoComments about safety issues ndash they are not going to build somethingit is not safe.George Robertson, also a community councillor, agreed that there was a need for improved accommodation in the town and felt the scheme could not be ldquocondemned out right.Ahead of the meeting, Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the group, said that there were mixed views within the community council.She said: ldquoI think we as a community council are going to be guided somewhat by the response of the neighbours.ldquoThe feedback from the community council has been mixed.ldquoThere is a genuine support for anything that would bring a high-quality addition to the accommodation offered in Dunbar.

title: column-frustrated-tories-power-grab
story: The Tory Government is trying to put in place a UK internal market following Brexit, where the devolved UK nations would have to adhere to Westminsterrsquos standards in future trade deals.The proposal would mean that Scotland would lose out on the power to agree to rules which would affect us, and decisions made in Westminster would be imposed on Scotland and the other devolved nations.Given Boris Johnsonrsquos track record, we know what this means for the UK and we should expect ridiculous trade deals with Trump which donrsquot meet basic standards.Though it seems currently that this is simply a constitutional argument, it is important that we realise the threat that this presents to our trade going forward.We do not want to see lowered food standards, or diminished safety standards on our goods.Clearly, Westminster are trying to push through a policy that means the Scottish, Welsh and Northern Irish Parliaments do not get a say in these matters, and it is important that we make sure this doesnrsquot happen.The Prime Minister seems to be in a panic over polls which show a majority for independence and is visiting Scotland to repair broken relationships as a result, but the Scottish people have had their eyes opened and seen the dangers of trusting a Tory Government.The coronavirus pandemic has proven their values, and we deserve a government that prioritises its people and their safety.I welcome the reopening of beauty salons and hairdressers and I know that this will be a relief for the many business owners who are seeking to reopen their salons, as well as to those who make use of their services.Beauty salons and hairdressers make a valuable contribution to our economy and I am glad that they will once again resume their business.

title: pans-snake-slithers-across-road-new-home
story: The Pans Snake has stretched from the eastern edge of Prestonpans towards neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton since it was born at the beginning of April.However, with plans for a temporary cycle path to be created beside busy Edinburgh Road, the snake had to find a new home... on the other side of the road.Emma Orphant was among those spending  minutes on Sunday evening moving the snake from the north side of the road.She said: ldquoWe lost count of the number of stones at ,!ldquoWe moved them across the road because the council are putting in a temporary cycle path.ldquoOn Sunday, volunteers and children moved them across the road.ldquoIt has just been a nice thing for people when they are out for a walk to look for.ldquoIt is for the kids.Youngsters and adults started working on the Pans Snake at the beginning of April, with lockdown restrictions in effect.Similar schemes have taken place where across the country, including the Windygoul Worm in Tranent.The snake started at the bus stop beside the Greenhills at Prestonpans, with Emma, who is depute manager at Seahorse Nursery in Cockenzie, keen to see it stretch the near half-mile to the neighbouring village.Emma, who lives in Prestonpans, was pleased to say that the snake had been a success and admitted she had a few favourite stones.She picked out those from youngsters saying they were missing school or with messages including their name and teacherrsquos name from school as her favourites.Beyond the coronavirus, Emma ndash and a number of people on social media ndash was keen to see the snake find a permanent home, with the possibility of the stones being cemented into the wall beside the footpath.

title: longniddry-gala-strikes-virtual-gold-50th-anniversary
story: The gala committee held a childrenrsquos disco in February but the committee still wanted to do something to remember the occasion so that it did not pass without a mention.Instead of its traditional celebrations, a competition was held which encouraged village residents to decorate their window, or more, with anything golden. A number of entries were submitted from people all over the village.First place went to Meg Anderson of Douglas Road second to Elizabeth Anderson-Whymark of Dean Road and third to Joanne Breckenridge of John Knox Road.To support local businesses, all of the winners were given East Lothian gt cards.Suzanne Low, Longniddry Gala committee member, said: ldquoWe would like to thank everyone who took part with golden decor ndash very good effort, I think yoursquoll agree.The committee hopes to celebrate the anniversary when possible.

title: luxury-hampers-given-students-covid-19-efforts
story: A total of pound, has been allocated by Santander Universities to provide gts to , students at QMU and Edinburgh Napier University who supported the NHS in the fight against the virus.QMU has offered its nursing and allied health professionsrsquo students on the frontline a choice of one of two luxury food hampers ndash a lsquopamper hamperrsquo or breakfast hamper.The gts have been provided by Artisan Larder Scotland, founded by QMU graduate David McVey.Edinburgh Napier University has linked up with East Lothian-based sushi company Minato Sushi to offer its own eligible School of Health and Social Care students a pound voucher for the business as a thank you for their efforts as part of the countryrsquos Covid- response.Sir Paul Grice, principal and vice-chancellor of Queen Margaret University, said: ldquoWe are incredibly proud of all of our students from the School of Health Sciences, especially those who are playing their part in the NHSrsquos fight against Covid-.ldquoThanks to the continuing generosity and support of Santander Universities, we have been able to not only provide this thank you gt for hundreds of our hard-working health students but also support one of our graduate businesses in the process."I hope the students enjoy the gt ndash they are doing fantastic work.

title: new-art-exhibition-highlights-beauty-dunbar
story: Edinburgh-based Ann Cowan spent time in the town throughout  and earlier this year.Her work ndash Dunbar Sketchbooks ndash will feature in Gullanersquos Fidra Fine Art, alongside Dominique Cameronrsquos Moor, which focuses on Rannoch Moor, west of Pitlochry.Although not the intention of either artist, both bodies of work are devoid of human figures.Ann, the daughter of an architect and an artist, found that her eye was naturally drawn to the architecture and streets in and around Dunbar.She said: ldquoThe town has a wealth of beautul old red sandstone buildings with interesting architectural details.ldquoOrange pan tiles form wonderful roofscapes.ldquoThe industrial outskirts are grittier, but just as interesting in terms of composition.ldquoThe harbour is a constant source of inspiration with its fishing boats and lobster creels.ldquoFollow the clfs of deep burnt sienna along the coast, past Winterfield to Belhaven and you discover miles of sandy beach with tall ochre grasses set against colourful beach chalets.Ann gave up a career in law to become a full-time artist.She grew up in the Borders, with Dunbar a town she has known for many years.Alan Rae, who owns the gallery, was a fan of both artists and was looking forward to the exhibition, which gets under way on August .He said: ldquoAnnrsquos loose and expressive drawing, sometimes supported by textural patches of collage, combines with an organic palette enlivened with flashes blue, yellow and the rich red of the local East Lothian sandstone.ldquoPainted in a spontaneous sketchbook style, the result is a broad and tender portrait of a much-loved town.The gallery owner said that the coronavirus lockdown had proven dficult for the arts sector.Fidra Fine Arts reopened its doors at the end of last month with the Mixed Summer Exhibition.Mr Rae added: ldquoWhen the lockdown began, it was a really anxious time.ldquoGallery owners always want to do the best for their artists and I wasnrsquot sure how it would play out with this exhibition.ldquoHappily, we will be welcoming visitors to view this wonderful work in August.

title: midge-repellents-top-tips-keep-scotlands-biting-beasties-bay
story: The dreaded midge isnt to be trled with. Weve all been there, sitting outside on a warm summers evening and enjoying a sunset, when there comes a tell-tale nip upon exposed flesh. The arm, the leg, the neck, the face, the scalp ndash the midge isnt fussy ndash and before you know it, youre under siege.With more of us set to enjoy staycations this year, we need to learn to coexist with these tiny flying brutes, which is why Im offering up my services as a human guinea pig. Im a good test subject given Ive never met a midge that doesnt like me.I still bear the scars ndash mental and physical ndash of a long weekend in Glen Coe a few years ago. It was July. There was cloud cover, no wind and a sticky humidity. I was almost eaten alive.Scotlands walks are never complete without the dreaded midgeBelieve me, I have tried everything to keep the midges at bay. Among the long list of suggestions that Ive given a whirl are eating Marmite sandwiches, spraying a fine mist of Listerine and taking garlic tablets .Smoke can act as a deterrent, which has seen me huddling next to barbecues and bonfires like they are two-bar electric fires on cold winter mornings.Ive donned midge nets that give me the forlorn air of a beekeeper who has lost her hive, or a grieving Victorian widow. Im considering putting up bat boxes after reading that a lone bat can eat , midges in one night.Citronella and Saltidinare among the ingredients that midges are said to find repugnant and give a wide berth. Essential oils such as eucalyptus, lavender and lemongrass have been credited with similar properties .The midge has a mighty reputation for such a miniscule insect. Weighing just one th of a gram, it has a teeny wingspan of -mm. Midges breed in vast numbers across  per cent of Scotlands land mass.Midges are said to enjoy the smell of our natural body odour and sweat which is where using certain scents can come in handy.Avon Skin So Soft , pound.This moisturiser wasnt designed with midges in mind but has famously been adopted for that purpose. When I interviewed the ultramarathon runner Dean Karnazes in , he mentioned that a friend had advised stocking up on Avon Skin So Soft would be prudent before a visit to Scotland.The Royal Marines are said to swear by its midge-repelling powers when training or based in and around the west coast.The secret to Skin So Soft creating a no-fly zone for midges has been widely attributed to the citronella that it contains.Skin So Soft has been my go-to over the years, clocking up a decent midge-busting hit rate.Application consistency: A dry oil spray.Smell: Baby talcum powder.Verdict: Still a classic. It has won an army of global fans for good reason.Visit avon.ukSmidge , pound.Wandering around shops and supermarkets across the Highlands during the summer months, you will see tourists clutching this elixir.Smidge has been about for a decade now. Its development was led by Dundee-based Dr Alison Blackwell, an authority on midge behaviour and leader of the team behind the Scottish Midge Forecast.The active ingredient is Saltidin which, according to the blurb, "has been molecularly designed to effectively block the antennal receptors of biting insects ndash basically, it throws them off your scent." Smidge is also billed as working on mosquitoes, black flies, sand flies, fleas and ticks.Application consistency: A lightweight, aluminium cannister with pump spray that dispels a fast-absorbing, water-based lotion.Smell: Chic unisex scent. Think CK One.Verdict: Did a stellar job as I sat in my tree-covered garden on a still, humid evening.Visit smidgeupMary Jean Highland Midge Lotion , poundThe idea of making a midge lotion is one that Elizabeth and Mary Quinn struck upon by chance. The owners of family-run Mary Jean in Fochabers, Moray, were selling their skincare products at a Highland Games in .The midges were biting and in a moment of inspiration, Mary soaked some kitchen roll in lemongrass oil and hung it from their stall. It worked a treat and an idea took seed, leading to the creation of Mary Jean Highland Midge Lotion.Ingredients include lemongrass ndash of course ndash as well as bog myrtle, aloe vera, jojoba, neem and mango. It is a wholesome product: handmade, organic, palm oil-free, vegan-friendly and non-toxic. Available in a ml travel size. Can also be used to deter mosquitoes and horseflies.Application consistency: A luxurious and light-feeling cream from a pump dispenser.Smell: Delicious citrus overtones.Verdict: A brilliant product that kept me midge-free. It also helped soothe redness on existing bites.Visit maryjeanAnderson Aromatics Beastie Be Gone , poundBeastie Be Gone, which launched in May, was coined by Bothwell-based clinical aromatherapist and perfumer Julie Anderson-McKee.As someone who loves the outdoors ndash Anderson-McKee can often be found camping in a tent or a caravan by a loch ndash she knows only too well the blight of midges.The result is a triple action cream that combines insect repellent, SPF  protection and a moisturiser that can be used as an after sun. It comes with excellent credentials, including being vegan, hypo-allergenic and as Anderson-McKee puts it "free from all nasties".Tried and tested by  Scottish wild campers and walkers, among the ingredients are organic shea butter, coconut and almond oils, lavender, lemon eucalyptus, citronella and myrrh.Application consistency: A sumptuous cream in a sleek metal container.Smell: Pleasant hints of lemon and lavender.Verdict: An impressive new kid on the block that does what it says on the tin.Visit andersonaromatics

title: scotlands-schools-four-key-updates-parents-ahead-reopening
story: Primary and secondary schools across the country closed their doors back in March to all but a few children.But with coronavirus in Scotland being suppressed to very low levels, things are looking optimistic regarding ato the classroom.Yesterday, education secretary John Swinney provided an update on schools.Teachers:The Scottish Government yesterday announced poundmillion of funding to employ hundreds of teachers and support staff to help schools re-open.An extra poundmillion was also pledged to cover other health protection costs.The funding will equate to around  teachers and  support staff.But as Labourrsquos education spokesperson, Iain Gray, pointed out, that accounts for only half a new member of staff per school across Scotland.August   Councils and schools have been working to the August date for some time.But the Scottish Government will not formally announce the August date until July .The Scottish Government has repeatedly stressed that reducing the infection rate is crucial to the reopening of schools, with the First Minister earlier in the week suggesting no more lockdown changes will be made until pupils are back in the classroom.Mr Swinney stressed that in Scotland, the infection rate is ldquoreducing by  per cent each week, but a sudden surge in cases over the next few weeks could sht the Scottish Governmentrsquos confidence that it is safe to re-open schools.Some pupils may have to socially distanceSocial distancingMr Swinney gave parents some much-needed details about the social distancing guidance that schools will be asked to follow ndash but some questions still remain over how this will work in practice.While primary pupils will not have to socially distance when theyon August , all being well, secondary schools will be told to enforce physical distancing rules ldquowhere possible.Mr Swinney said this was due to the scientic advice on social distancing being ldquoless clear for older pupils.Meanwhile secondary schools will be asked to adjust the layout of classrooms and manage flows of people in and out of buildings ndash but with a catch.This social distancing rule in secondary schools will be ldquosubject always to this not reducing capacity within the school.Youth clubsAs well as earmarking pound million for school staff and pound million to help councils meet extra costs in re-opening classrooms, pound million of previously announced money will be used to support youth work in connection with schools being re-opened.Mr Swinney said this funding has been announced as the sector has ldquocontinued to support and engage children and young people through the pandemic, highlighting the use of digital technology to help mitigate the impact of the lockdown on young peoplersquos mental health.

title: face-masks-scotland-two-key-mistakes-everyone-making
story: So far, just one person has been handed a pound fine for not complying with the rules ndash as the country tries to further control the suppression of the coronavirus.The Scottish Government say that in enclosed spaces, where physical distancing is more dficult with people who are not members of your household, you should wear a face covering.By law, you must wear a covering in shops and on public transport ndash with similar rules coming into force in England today.But there are some parts of the guidance that many people seem to be forgetting.They are:Who Is exempt from wearing a covering Some people are not required to wear a face covering.These include:You are required by law to wear a face covering in Scotlands shops and on public transport .Find out how you can #StaySafe and protect others ##You may also have a reasonable excuse not to wear a face covering , for example:Inidual discretion should be applied in considering the use of face coverings for other children including, for example, children with breathing dficulties and disabled children who would struggle to wear a face covering.

title: 13-unusual-quirky-places-holiday-scotland
story: With the nationrsquos tourism sector now reopened, wersquove put together a list of some of our favourite awe-inspiring holiday accommodation.Places that bring together architectural wizardry and painstaking refurbishment to breathe new le ndash and use ndash into everything from a lighthouse to a modern-day broch and erstwhile modes of transportation, including buses, train carriages and even a helicopter.Roulotte Retreat, near Melrose, Scottish BordersThere is something wonderfully romantic about this circle of seven colourful roulotteslocated in a pretty wildflower meadow below the Eildon Hills.Each roulotte faces onto a lochan at the centre of the site. Facilities include sunset decks, wood-burning stoves, eco saunas and hot tubs. Itrsquos a perfect getaway for nature lovers with owls, deer, foxes, and badgers among the regular visitors.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit roulotteretreatHelicopter Glamping, Mains Farm Wigwams, Thornhill, StirlingStay in a Sea King helicopter complete with mini kitchen, bathroom and a cockpit seating area offering stunning views over the Forth Valley. The helicopter ndash part of Mains Farm Wigwams ndash sleeps two adults or a family of five . Therersquos a double bed, a single bed in the tail and seating which converts into a second double bed. The owners are currently renovating a  Scottish Aviation Twin Pioneer plane set to open for overnight stays next year.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit mainsfarmwigwamsSleeperzzz, Rogart, SutherlandChoose between a vintage railway carriage, a freight wagon or the Waiting Room BB.Located beside a ing train station at Rogart , Sleeperzzz offers budget accommodation for backpackers, families, walkers, cyclists or those who simply fancy spending the night somewhere a bit dferent ndash such as a -ton goods van from the s.A great base for exploring Dunrobin Castle and the North Coast .Prices from poundpp per night. Call   or visit sleeperzzzCraighead Howfs, Dunblane, PerthshireBe transported to The Shire ndash which could be Perthshire or JRR Tolkienrsquos fictional Middle-earth in The Lord of the Rings, depending on how you look at it ndash with these magical Hobbit Howfs.The Burrow and Bagend are built into the hillside with grassy roofs and round doors for an unforgettable glamping experience. Craighead Howfs also offers the chance to stay in a treehouse with panoramic views over the Ochils and a secluded summer house.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit craigheadhowfThe Bus Stop, Gford, East LothianIf you have ever wanted to enjoy a Summer Holiday in the vein of the  film, look no further. This fleet of buses in a field belonging to an arable farm in East Lothian have been transformed into holiday accommodation with armchairs, sofas, lanterns, hot flasks, log stoves and beds.Each bus has a private wood-fired hot tub and barbecue fire pit. Choose from rustic or luxury ndash the latter have en suite bathrooms and swish mod cons. Oh, and therersquos gorgeous views of the Lammermuir Hills.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit thebusstop.scotBrockloch Eco Retreat, Kirkpatrick Durham, Castle DouglasFeatured on George Clarkersquos Amazing Spaces, Brockloch Eco Retreat is small but perfectly formed. Located on a working farm, therersquos two units: a contemporary, off-grid, micro-timber bothy facing into an open field and an incredible treehouse hideaway within a bluebell wood where the closest neighbours are red squirrels.The treehouse has a built-in double bed with a skylight to gaze at the treetops and stars as you drt off to sleep. This part of the world is a great place to see red kites.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit brocklochBlack Isle Yurts, Eathie Hill, RosemarkieSet in private woodland, all of the yurts within this eco-sensitive, wild-glamping site are based on designs used by nomadic people in Central Asia for thousands of years.In keeping with the Scottish climate, the traditional felt outer shell has been replaced with a waterproof canvas and therersquos a wood-burning stove to stay cosy on cooler nights. The site is a short drive from Chanonry Point which is fantastic for dolphin spotting.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit blackisleyurtsRua Reidh Lighthouse, near Gairloch, Wester RossBuilt in  by David Alan Stevenson, a cousin of the writer Robert Louis Stevenson and one of the famous ldquoLighthouse Stevensons, this beautul, remote location offers BB and self-catering, the latter in the charmingly named First Officerrsquos Quarters.Endless views, a glorious stretch of coastline, abundant bird and sea le, tranquillity, solitude and the thrill of potentially catching a glimpse of the Aurora Borealis on dark, starry nights awaits.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit stayatalighthouseCalgary, MullNot to be confused with the skyscraper-filled city in Alberta, this little corner of Mull is a delight.A byre, hayloft and dovecote are among the self-catering properties available at Calgary, each with its own distinctive character. Calgary also has an excellent cafe, art gallery and a woodland sculpture walk.Therersquos a beach within strolling distance where Robinrsquos Boat sells Isle of Mull ice cream. Sea eagles, otters and basking sharks can all be seen nearby.Prices start from pound for a seven-night stay. Call   or visit calgaryThe Scriptorium Apartments at St Benedictrsquos Abbey, Fort AugustusThe Scriptorium ndash the once secret writing room of the monastery ndash has two one-bedroom apartments with vaulted ceilings, gothic archways and stained-glass windows. Therersquos plenty to do in the grounds and gardens, be it tennis, badminton, croquet or giant chess. The former Monksrsquo Refectory has been converted into a Club Lounge and a chapel refurbished to incorporate a heated pool, sauna and steam room.Prices start from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit parrandierThe Brochs of Coigach, near Achiltibuie, UllapoolBrochs are an ancient dwelling found only in Scotland, dating back to BC. Gille Buidhersquos Broch and Scalrsquos Broch are a bit younger than thatand beautully enchanting structures.If you love upcycling, they will impress, built using stones from old, crumbling walls on nearby land and timber recovered from a dilapidated Victorian pier. Oil paintings by John Bellany hang on the walls, alongside display cabinets filled with weird and wonderful objects.Prices from pound per night. Call   or visit thebrochsThe Four Sisters Boatel, EdinburghTucked away in the heart of the Scottish capital, this houseboat is permanently moored at the Lochrin Basin on the Union Canal ndash the eastern terminus for the -mile stretch of water that comes all the way from Falkirk. Sleeping up to six adults and two children, it is an ideal base to explore Edinburgh, with Bruntsfield and the West End, as well as the Old and New Towns, all just a stonersquos throw away.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit thefoursistersThe Sawmill at Glen Dye, Banchory, AberdeenshireTalk about enjoying the great outdoors in style. Stay in a sleek, refurbished s Airstream Safari caravan in a small pine wood beside the fast flowing lade of a sawmill.A rustic, wooden seed store with roots back to the s serves as the kitchen, dining and sitting room. There are games, books, a record player and a memorable barbecue spot. Glen Dye also offers a river cabin, a bothy and two steading cottages, as well as running residential courses in crafts and wild food.Prices start from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit glendyecabinsandcottages

title: big-changes-furlough-scheme-august-1----need-know
story: Employers across the UK have until Friday to submit claims for furloughed staff for periods ending on or before June .The UK Government introduced new rules at the start of the month, allowing furloughed employees back to work for any amount of time or sht pattern.Employers would pay the wages for those days, with the UK Government still pay the % grant ndash up to a cap of pound per month ndash on the days not worked.But from Saturday, August , more major changes are to come into effect.What are the changes From Saturday, the level of grant will be reduced each month until the scheme ends on October .Chancellor Rishi SunakWhat does this mean for employers From this date, employers will be required to start contributing more eachmonth.They will also have to start paying National Insurance Contributions and pension contributions for the hours the employee is on furlough.From September , employers will be made to contribute % towards the wage payments ndash which will be added on to % provided by the UK Government.And From October , employers will have to contribute %, added on to % by the UK Government.Full details can be found here.What does this mean for furloughed staff The good news for you is that your wages will remain the same.You will continue to receive % of your salary ndash but the dference is just the adjustment of what your employer pays, and what the state pays.How many people are furloughed in Scotland According to figures published on July , nearly , people in Scotland have been helped by the furlough and self-employment support schemes.UK government figures show that, up to the end of June, , Scots had been furloughed.In addition, another , claims have been made to the scheme supporting self-employed workers during the lockdown period.What is the title: coronavirus-pet-cat-becomes-first-animal-uk-confirmed-case
story: Heres the latest on what we know so far.When was the test carried out The infection was confirmed following tests at the Animal and Plant Health Agencylaboratory in Weybridge, Surrey, on Wednesday, July .What have Public Health England said Yvonne Doyle, medical director at Public Health England , said: ldquoThis is the first case of a domestic cat testing positive for Covid- in the UK but should not be a cause for alarm.ldquoThe investigation into this case suggests that the infection was spread from humans to animal, and not the other way round.ldquoAt this time, there is no evidence that pets can transmit the disease to humans.ldquoIn line with the general advice on fighting coronavirus, you should wash your hands regularly, including before and after contact with animals.A private vet initially diagnosed the pet with feline herpes virus, a common cat respiratory infection, but the sample was also tested for Covid- part of a research programme.The case has been reported to the World Organisation for Animal Health in line with international agreements.Have other cases in pets been reported There have been a small number of confirmed cases in pets in other countries in Europe, North America and Asia.What has the UKs chief veterinary officer said The UKrsquos chief veterinary officer, Christine Middlemiss, said: ldquoTests conducted by the Animal and Plant Health Agency have confirmed that the virus responsible for Covid- has been detected in a pet cat in England.ldquoThis is a very rare event, with infected animals detected to date only showing mild clinical signs and recovering within a few days.ldquoThere is no evidence to suggest that pets directly transmit the virus to humans.ldquoWe will continue to monitor this situation closely and will update our guidance to pet owners should the situation change.

title: Opinion  Marianne Taylor  We   re all public health guinea pigs now    but that   s just the way it has to be
story: Irsquove also started planning a wee holiday up north and have booked a hairdressersrsquo appointment. Irsquove looked out my monthly cinema pass in anticipation of re-opening around July .I appreciate not everyone feels this way, but Irsquom ready to start living again. Irsquom also ready to accept some fundamental political realities.Letrsquos face it, wersquore all just guinea pigs now, part of a radical public health experiment the likes of which has never been attempted before. This experiment is reaching its most dficult phase yet, the bit where the Government has to somehow let people start doing normal things ndash like going back to work and spending money to keep the economy going ndash while simultaneously reminding us that we wersquore not out of the woods yet. They have to encourage people to go out, while keeping them scared.Many ndash including me ndash have criticised politicians for their missteps and mixed messages over the last few months. But I also recognise a number of basic truths that itrsquos better to get onersquos head around sooner rather than later, regardless of party politics.The first is that until coronavirus has been completely eradicated around the world, risk is going to play a part in our lives for the foreseeable future. The second is closely related: the state cannot tell us exactly how to manage this risk in every single circumstance. We may get health advice and government guidance, but ultimately we have to navigate this new, more precarious world on our own.How we do this, and, crucially, how we feel about doing it, depends on many dferent things, of course, not least our age and underlying health, our financial situation and, to a signicant extent, our personality.I know there are some who believe that through lting lockdown restrictions politicians in Westminster and Holyrood are very deliberately handing over responsibility ndash and thus blame ndash to the public for what comes next. And there may be some truth to this. But come on, letrsquos get real.Accusations of ldquomaking it up as they go along are thrown around asthis was an insult rather than simply a fact describing the predicament governments everywhere find themselves in. How could it be otherwise given the extraordinary events of the last six months  And whatrsquos the alternative to us being public health guinea pigs  Staying at home forever Community levels of the virus in Scotland are now low and falling. Our hospitals lie empty. We have a test and trace system in place to ndash hopefully ndash crack down on infections. Meanwhile, wellbeing continues to suffer under the restrictions and hundreds of thousands of jobs hang in the balance. All of these things mean we can and should lt the lockdown. And lting restrictions means the vast majority of folkmust decide for themselves what level of risk they are comfortable contending with, taking into consideration how it might affect their family and community as well as their own personal circumstances.We can help ourselves along the way. Firstly by staying up to date ndash through trusted, legitimate scientic and public information sources ndash about how the virus is transmitted and the best ways to stay safe.We can also resist the temptation to judge others for their decisions. Frankly, Irsquom sick of the army of armchair virologists spouting their culture war vitriol on social media. On one side you have those who seem to relish the lockdown, the class swots who shout too loudly about how they follow every part of the guidanceand seem to revel in the idea of a second wave. On the other side, you have the virus deniers. Both groups peddle fear and misinformation, whether that is their intention or not.At the end of the day none of us, not even the scientists, know whether and when there will be another wave of the virus. Uncertainty permeates through every part of our lives now, and we must find ways to live with and even embrace thiswe are to make it through the tough months ahead. Letrsquos at least try to respect each otherrsquos dferent ways of coping, shall we All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: gardening-empty-space-veg-patch-boost-soil-green-manure-crops
story: If youve spare room on your allotment, or in your garden, for crops that will fill empty spaces and boost your soil, consider plants that can turn into green manure.You may have harvested potatoes and onions, but plant some fast-germinating replacements and youll stop weeds from growing, keep the goodness in, and help soil structure.What are green manures They are crops that can help improve your plots structure, stop nutrients from being washed out by rain, and provide good ground cover to stop weeds emerging. Those that belong to the pea and bean familyfor example, in summer, can store nitrogen in their roots,that can be ploughed back into the earth.Which crops make good green manures At this time of year they include mustard, fodder radish, fenugreek, buckwheat and phacelia, which can be slotted in in six to eight week gaps when the ground is cleared between crops. Some sown in early autumn, including winter beans, grazing rye and winter tares, will last through the winter and can be dug into the soil when it warms up in spring.How long do they take to grow Some, such as mustard, are fast-germinating. Two weeks after sowing youll find the ground covered with small seedlings, and after six weeks, these can be chopped and folded into the soil to add nutrients.Fenugreek is another nitrogen-fixer for summer, really fast growing and its bushy plants are great for suppressing weeds. It can be planted in late spring or summer and grown for up to three months.When do I cut them down Chop the fast-growing ones when you need the ground back. Just dig them up, chopping up the leaves and stems as you go to speed up decomposition. Leave them a few days to wilt and then dig them into the soil.Longer term crops such as alfalfa, red clover and trefoil can be left in the ground for a year and clipped from time to time to stop them from going woody. They are ideal for soil thats been overused and needs to rest.What benefits do they provide Clover, fenugreek, winter beans and alfalfa are good nitrogen-fixers, storing nitrogen in their roots, while clover and phacelia flowers are a magnet for beneficial insects, which can help pollinate crops, so leave some to flower. Italian ryegrass and buckwheat have root systems that will help break up heavy ground.When can I plant crops in the space again A few weeks after youve dug in your green manure, you can sow late crops such as onion and garlic.WhatI want to wait If you have no crops to fill the space, cover the green manure-treated bed with cardboard or landscape fabric to keep the nutrients from the green manure in, which will give you a great seedbed to sow seeds in come spring.What  can I grow to help my crops Try growing comfrey, which absorbs nutrients and minerals and can be made into a liquid feed. Just cut it down to the ground, fill a bucket with the leaves and stems of the plant, packing them in tightly and then filling the bucket with water.Set it aside for three weeks , then strain off the liquid into a container with a tight lid. When you want to feed your plants, dilute the liquid with water at a ratio of around : and feed your plants weekly into autumn.

title: books-peter-geoghegan-dark-money-reshaped-political-agenda
story: Peter GeogheganHead of Zeus, pound.Review by Fiona RintoulON reaching chapter four of Peter Geogheganrsquos meticulously researched and highly readable new book Democracy for Sale: Dark Money and Dirty Politics, I emitted a small scream of ldquoNo!. Irsquod just learnt that ldquothe most blatant example of dark money in recent electoral politics can be traced to the south Glasgow suburb of Clarkston.The poundk-plus that the Democratic Unionist Partyspent on pro-Brexit advertising in the run up to the June  referendum on the UKrsquos membership of the European Union ndash not in Northern Ireland but Great Britain ndash was donated by an obscure body named the Constitutional Research Council . Its only named director was Richard Cook, a multiply-failed Tory candidate of Clarkston parish.This incident is totemic of the tawdry tale of secretive donors and anonymous propaganda that Geoghegan, investigations editor at independent media  openDemocracy and founder of the award-winning investigative website The Ferret, painstakingly weaves in Democracy for Sale. There are a few diamond mines and Russian ambassadors, itrsquos true, but in the main this story unfolds in unstimulating locales and features compromised mediocrities such as Cook.His business interests are nearly as convoluted as those of Arron Banks, one of the self-proclaimed ldquoBad Boys of Brexit. Drawing on the resources of a miasma of offshore companies, Banks bankrolled the belligerent, anti-immigration Leave.EU campaign with the ldquobiggest donation in British political history.The National Crime Agency investigated Banksrsquo pound.m donation to anti-EU causes amid mounting speculation about the source of the funds, but found no evidence of wrongdoing. Banks hailed the ruling as vindication of his Brexit campaign, but others saw it as ldquotacit acceptance that companies in offshore jurisdictions could underwrite political donations.The campaign for Brexit mingled such offshore money with obscure onshore funding. The CRCrsquos donation to the DUP encapsulates the problem. The CRC is an unincorporated association, not subject to the normal disclosure requirements that an incorporated company must meet. According to Geoghegan, unincorporated associations are ldquoblack boxes that can be set up for the sole purpose of funnelling money to political campaigns, with little or no transparency.The influential European Research Groupis also an unincorporated association. Geoghegan shows how the ERG, a party within a party that ldquobrought down a Conservative prime minister and called the tune on Brexit, was able to trouser around pound, in taxpayer money between  and  ldquothanks to a little-used Westminster convention. Another scream moment.The tale of how dark money reshaped the political agenda in the UK and beyond pullulates with such dim-lit legal entities. The same people and companies ndash Cambridge Analytica, Dominic Cummings, Nigel Farage ndash keep reappearing from the mists of an opaque complex of vested interests.Geoghegan claries that he does not believe Brexit was ldquosome grand conspiracy. The British state and the political and business establishment were behind Remain. Instead, he says, the referendum and its aftermath reveal something more fundamental and systemic: ldquoa broken political system that is ripe for exploitation.Arguably, the groundwork for Brexit ndash and for Donald Trump and Boris Johnsonrsquos victories at the ballot box ndash was laid by another brand of unaccountable entity: the think tank. In theory, think tanks do research and publish research papers in practice, says Geoghegan, ldquoWords like lsquoinstitutersquo and lsquocentrersquo give an appearance of academic rigour to what is essentially paid-for lobbying.In the book, Geoghegan illuminates a network of libertarian think tanks that have sought to shunt the political agenda to the right in the UK and the US. Of course, there are left-leaning think tanks too, but, as Geoghegan notes, they are generally more transparent about their funding, as they rely on public money and donations from trusts.Anonymous funding makes think tanks the ideal vehicle for business interests to influence government policy beneath the radar. Geoghegan shows how a ldquotiny group of American plutocrats invested billions in think tanks, universities and election campaigns over the last four decades. ldquoBefore this methodical and precisely targeted spending spree, libertarians had been largely thought of as cranks, he writes. ldquoAfterwards, the limited space within which policies are created and publicly discussed was filled with proposals that they wanted.The ldquogrande dame of libertarian think tanks is the Institute for Economic Affairsin London. Geoghegan reveals how the IEArsquos ldquosunny analysis about Brexit and unprecedented access to ministers helped determine the UK governmentrsquos course after the referendum. The IEA also worked to promote the idea of the Anglosphere in the UK ndash a union of English-speaking people as a bulwark against Brussels bureaucrats first mooted by Margaret Thatcher in .Democracy for Sale appears just as the UK government publishes its long-awaited report into alleged Russian interference in UK politics. Geoghegan touches on Russian influence in the UK and beyond, but the bulk of the dark money and misinformation that he documents sits much closer to home.ldquoHiding in plain sight is a phrase that recurs throughout this book. The ultimate source of the money donated to the DUP by the CRC in the run-up to the EU referendum was protected not by cloak-and-dagger Brexiteers but by Northern Irish legislation. Subsequent Electoral Commission inquiries into the donation proved toothless. ldquoThe system is broken, and nobody intends to fix it, transparency activist Tamasin Cave tells Geoghegan.In ldquothe digital Wild West, accountability is in even shorter supply. Geoghegan conjures a blizzard of examples of the disturbing ways in which digital campaigning can be used to undermine democratic mechanisms, from targeted messaging to voter suppression.In this shadowy world, truth is the first casualty. During the  general election campaign, the Conservative Party rebranded its Twitter account as FactcheckUK with no consequences. However, all the blame for the increasing role of unregulated digital campaigning in our politics cannot be laid at the door of right-wing parties. Barack Obama was one of the first to harness its power.Written in crisp, vivid prose, Democracy for Sale is a dense but compelling narrative that takes us from the backstreets of Washington DC to Viktor Orbagravenrsquos Hungary. Above all, it is a call to arms, and everyone who is concerned about our democracy should read it.While Geoghegan remains an optimist, he does not hide the scale or urgency of the challenge. ldquoLike the climate, democracy is fast reaching a tipping point, he warns.

title: food-chef-tom-kerridge-shares-passion-bbqs
story: Barbecues at the ready because chef Tom Kerridge, holder of two Michelin stars, has a trove of summertime cooking treats to share.During the course of his new show, Tom Kerridge Barbecues - on the Food Network, the chef will be showing off some old and new recipes using charcoal, smoke and fire.He talks about his favourite dish from the series and why everyone - including professional chefs - are prone to barbecue disasters from time to time.How did this series come about "I filmed with Food Network last year, a big series for the States, they gave me a call and said listen do you want to do something with barbecues... it was actually a really good, fun thing to do. Im interested in barbecue cookery, its not professional, its much more about social cookery. I love that very much and the idea of making a TV show relatively quickly, getting it turned around, getting it out there, with people that Ive made TV with before, its just like Well, this would be a great way to spend a couple of weeks doing stuff."When did you film "We finished filming Thursdayand the first episode airs on July . So as we were filming, its going into the edit straight away, so its a very quick turnaround and an exciting way of making television."Given that, did you feel pressurised or quite relaxed "Not pressure but it felt quite energised because it was quite a quick turnaround ... Look its not important TV, but its fun TV. Im not making a documentary on Covid- am I  Im cooking beef brisket so its kind of like, its not pressure but its been fun and quick so the energy has been great."If you cook one thing on a barbecue for the rest of your le, what would it be "I think probably short ribs of beef or beef brisket something thats slow-cooked, loads of flavour, they are the sort of things I love cooking. They take a bit more time, but that kind of effort and energy that comes through slow cooking is amazing."Do you have a favourite dish from this series "They are really all good, there are lots of things Ive done on there that have been fantastic. One of the loveliest ones to do was a Spanish kind of chorizo pork burger, so its like a burger butthose lovely warming Spanish flavours it makes you feel very much like its summer time - so its a play on a burger with just a bit more."Have you had any real barbecue disasters "We all have them... barbecue is one of those ways you cook, its sensual and touch and understanding and its not always controlled, its not controlled like a grill or a hob, or whatever  youve got in the kitchen. It is about the coals and the way that theyve been formed. So quite often, things will stick on the barbecue and its learning your way around it and the kind of things you can do to make things not, stick, things sticking on a BBQ haunts everybody, its not just you or anybody  at home - its everyone!"What are your top tips for having a successful barbecue "Planning and preparation is key. Last minute barbecuing is good but you end up just going to stick some sausages on it. Actually to get the best barbecue... planning, structure and marinading or briningor dry rubs, they all take planning, so thats probably the best tip."Have you had a barbecue that sticks in your mind "My th birthday was pretty special,a few years ago, we had round about  people there and we had nine big, egg-style barbecues cooking and we had pretty much every Michelin star chef in the country came and they all bought things to cook on the barbecue, so it was like a massive chef party with loads of people cooking loads of food on barbecues, it was an outstanding day."Has lockdown brought people together, given us a sense of community spirit "Yes, absolutely. It has strengthened community spirit, everyone has taken care of each other, they are all looking out for each other. Particularly within the hospitality industry, have shown themselves as a caring and giving sector that has really wanted to help in any way possible, no matter where you are in the country."Have you found it dficult to keep healthy during lockdown and what have you been doing to keep fit Obviously getting to the gym has been a no-no, so watching what I eat is at the forefront of my mind, and getting out and doing a run, evenI dont enjoy it, forcing myself to move has kept my joints going!Tom Kerridge Barbecues airs from July  at pm on Food Network and will be available on dplay

title: motoring-five-best-electric-vans-sale-today
